dialogues.text: He was just- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: One. The Man flinches, lowers the cane. He regards Nat and Sam with equal disdain before slinking away, pulling his wife along with him. Samuel helps Nat to his feet. Nat and the young boy catch eyes long enough to see the boy’s innocen face curl into a scowl.

SLAVE DRIVER (CONT’D) Consider this comely wench! Not a day over eighteen! We'll start her at one seventy-five. A REDNECK #2 tips his hat. SLAVE DRIVER (CONT’D) Got one seventy-five, I hear two? dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Massa... That wench there’d sho’ make a good weddin’ gift to Ms. Catherine. You keep sayin’ she been askin.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVE DRIVER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Gimmie Two-fifty! C’mon nah! A long beat. Until-

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: The whole lot of ‘em looks busted from here. Sides, she look right young if you ask me. Angle on Redneck #3 who again raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVE DRIVER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There it is! Two seventy-five?! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: You right, suh. She young, but with the right teachin’, a wench like that could be working a long time. Nat steals a look to Samuel who squints toward the stage. Slave Driver spins the Slave Woman in a circle, fondles h brest. She tenses.

dialogues.text: Now is you fella’s seein’ what I’m seeing?! Take this one home, clean her up, won't be long ‘fore you find yourself happier than a dog with three balls! A few chuckles in response. He spins her back forward. SLAVE DRIVER (CONT’D) (sotto, to slave woman) smile bitch! (she weakly complies) Now come on y’all, talk to me! (to Redneck #2) You got two seventy-five for me? Redneck #2 mulls.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Massa, it'd shole’ be a shame to watch her go to waste for such a low price.

dialogues.text: What you know about what's little and what's a lot? Nat falls quiet.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ain't sure what's got into you, but whatever it is, you need to quit it.

dialogues.text: Yes, suh.

dialogues.text: (ecstatic) We got two seventy-five! Do. I Hear. Three hundred?!

dialogues.text: Go’on and stay with Hark a spell “til we get this child right an’ on her feet. 29a 42 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: HARK
dialogues.text: Hey, Nat.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Hey, brother... Nat takes a seat next to him.

dialogues.speaker: NAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shouldn't you be somewhere getting to know your new wife?

dialogues.speaker: HARK
dialogues.text: I'll be getting there directly...

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: It was beautiful today. Ester is a good woman. Hark studies the smoldering fire. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HARK
dialogues.text: I'm scared, Nat...

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Of what? (playful) Ester?

dialogues.text: Naw... It’s just, I ain't never had no needs to look after nothing or nobody but massa’s horses and pigs. Now I got a wife. And when she go on and get the ‘big belly, I’11 have that child too. Nat pulls a measured breath, gathers his words.

dialogues.text: I want you to have it. (then) In case I don’t see you for a while, you'll have somethin’ reminds you of me.

dialogues.text: I don’t know if it’s right I take it. ‘Sides I don’t have nothin’ to give you to remind you of me.

dialogues.text: Cherry nearly drops the plates. Nat climbs down.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nat? What you doing here? No answer. Nat walks boldly to her, his eyes glued to her He leans in, kisses her softly on her lips.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I shoulda’ done that earlier today.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: You came here to kiss me? Nat slowly sinks to one knee.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I ain’t got much. The Lord. My faith. Mamma. Nana. Up until now, it was enough. (beat) Cherry, I'd feel right honored if you'd be my wife. I'd treat you right. I'd protect you with my life... if you’d have me.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: (smiles) Yes. I will. Nat rises. Kisses her lips again.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What now?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I'll talk it over with Samuel. Get a cabin set up for us. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: A final kiss before Nat slowly backs away from her, shado engulfing him into the night. Cherry smiles, breaths deep if for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nat and Cherry are knelt in front of Bridget who prays fervently. Nancy, Hark, Ester and a few others “lay hands Nat and Cherry’s shoulders praying along silently in supp INT. SLAVE QUARTERS - NAT’S CABIN - (NIGHT) 53 Nat and Cherry are in Nat's cabin. He gently kisses her a they make love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend Walthall climbs the porch steps. As he grabs the railing, it comes off into his hand. He carefully replace it, continues to the door and knocks. Samuel arrives, pus open the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: Reverend. What brings you around these parts during the week? Wouldn't expect to see you til Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: REV. WALTHALL
dialogues.text: There's never a wrong time to bring a blessing to a brother in Christ.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: Oh, Lord. Is this blessin’ gonna cost me money?

dialogues.speaker: REV. WALTHALL
dialogues.text: Ha! Not a penny. The contrary in fact. Sam joins him on the porch. They sit on adjacent rockers.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: Isaiah! Run some waters out here.

dialogues.speaker: REV. WALTHALL
dialogues.text: Gin, if you please. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH
dialogues.text: (fom inside) Yes’suh.

dialogues.speaker: REV. WALTHALL
dialogues.text: I put the word out about your preacher. Got a couple farmers willing to turn a good coin.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: That right? Isaiah serves the drinks, before disappearing into the ho SAMUEL TURNER (CONT’D) How much they offering.

dialogues.speaker: REV. WALTHALL
dialogues.text: A bit. And these days every bit counts. (then) If your boy does to these fellas’ liking, you could bounce back from the drought, pay off some debt. Soon enough, find yourself riding the gravy train with biscuit wheels. Samuel stares off as he considers.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: Whereabouts are we talkin’.

dialogues.speaker: REV. WALTHALL
dialogues.text: All in Southampton to start.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: An all I gotta do is have Nat preach?

dialogues.speaker: REV. WALTHALL
dialogues.text: That’s it. (beat) Now, I’m not vouching for the character of these fellas, what business they running or how, I’m just telling you there’s a opportunity here, one you got the means to capitalize on.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: (finally nods) Sounds good enough. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: REV. WALTHALL
dialogues.text: Alright, then. I’1l send you the details names, locations and dates by tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: You already booked the dates?

dialogues.speaker: REV. WALTHALL
dialogues.text: I figured you'd say yes.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: You're going mighty far outta your way make sure my cabinets are stocked full. What’s in all this for you.

dialogues.speaker: REV. WALTHALL
dialogues.text: Just the joy of knowing I’m helping my fellow brother. And...

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: Here it comes...

dialogues.speaker: REV. WALTHALL
dialogues.text: If I were to receive a “gift offering” following the successful completion of such trips, I certainly would not object. A shared smile.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: You are a caution Reverend.

dialogues.speaker: REV. WALTHALL
dialogues.text: I am but a servant. (then, rising) First trip’d be day after tomorrow, if you can pony up by then.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: Shouldn't be a problem.

dialogues.speaker: REV. WALTHALL
dialogues.text: Good. The men shake hands before Rev. Walthall climbs into his carriage. His SLAVE snaps the reins and Samuel watches th carriage advance down the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nat loads the last of supplies onto the wagon. Bridget st close. Nancy arrives with a cloth sack.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Got some salt pork and tomatoes in here, for when you get hungry.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Thanks, mama. (then) If Miss Catherine brings Cherry on Sunday, tell her I'll be back directly. Nancy nods solemnly. NAT (CONT’D) Don’t y’all go getting worried, now. I’1l be back soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGET
dialogues.text: I know. The Lord bless you, child. At that, Nat wraps Nancy and Bridget into a hug before heading off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --AERIAL SHOT of the wagon as it makes its way across the Eastern Virginia landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Nat guides the wagon toward a prosperous estate, he is by a slave JASPER (13, tattered clothes, rail thin).

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: You Marse Turner’s nigger?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I’m Nat. (re: back of wagon) Master Turner is restin’ in here. Jasper cranes his neck to see inside. He eyes Nat suspiciously, then-

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Come on. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jasper leads them toward the porch stairs of the main hou before disappearing inside. Samuel emerges. Looks around.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: We here?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Yes’ suh. A youngin’ just went inside to fetch Mister Randall. Seconds later a plump man, JOSEPH RANDALL (50's) emerges, followed by a muscular house servant ABNER (40'S) and Jas

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH RANDALL
dialogues.text: Sam Turner. You made it. And right on time. Randall sticks out his hand. Samuel shakes it. ANGLE ON ABNER Who stares daggers into Nat.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH RANDALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Joseph Randall. (xe: house servant) This here’s Abner. The little one there’s Jasper. (then, re: Nat) This the ‘nigger preacher’?

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: (to Nat) Nat?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Evenin’ Suh-

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH RANDALL
dialogues.text: A little young ain't he?

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: He’s old enough. Been studyin’ the Word a while.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH RANDALL
dialogues.text: Studying? Hell, I can barely train my niggers to learn their own names... C’mon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57A EXT. RANDALL PLANTATION - DAY 57a Samuel and Nat follow Joseph, Jasper and Abner along a wo path. Joseph walks and talks.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH RANDALL
dialogues.text: It’s hard times for small farmers like you and myself. Breaking even is hard enough, gettin’ ahead is impossible. To save some, I cut ‘em down to a meal a day, per head. A few of ‘em started gettin’ fidgety, so I had Abner come down on ‘em. The group approaches a dilapidated barn, a PADLOCK secure the door FROM THE OUTSIDE. Joseph stops short. JOSEPH RANDALL (CONT’D) Day or so back, had a few quit on work if ya’ can believe it. Wouldn't even come out the quarter. So I locked ‘em up, the lot of ‘em. Hoping the heat and hunger would bring about their senses. All that said, Abner here’s provin’ my only real protection. Joseph turns to Nat.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH RANDALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, they needs to mind me, so you speak on that. They treasure in heaven from submittin’ and all. (then) If they gets to moaning and carrying on, don’t pay ‘em no mind. They lazy as all hell and’ll do anything to get out of work.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH RANDALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ready, boy?

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: He's ready. With that Abner keys open the padlock; opens the barn doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph and Abner lead Nat and Samuel in. Abner lights a lantern. Under its glow, we see nearly a dozen EMACIATED slaves- men, women and children. They scatter deep into a corner. Nat's jaw drops. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6/15/15 - YELLOW 44a

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH RANDALL
dialogues.text: Listen up. Got a preacher here f'yall. (to Nat) (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH RANDALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come here, boy. (Nat slowly approaches) He's a nigger just like yall, and is going to talk to you about the Lord. Listen to him and you just might make it to heaven, ya hear? Joseph rejoins Samuel and Abner, leaving Nat standing in center of the room. Nat looks to Samuel who looks away. Through sad eyes, Nat studies the sea of skeletal faces a festering whip wounds. He swallows, peels open his Bible.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: ...Brothers and sisters. (re: slaves, unblinking I lead you to 1 Peter 2:18: Slaves... submit yourselves to your masters with all respect, not only to those who are good and considerate... but also to those who are hars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nat glances toward Randall who smiles and nods him on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nat pulls the wagon to the front, just as Samuel and Jose descend the porch stairs. Abner trails a few steps back.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH RANDALL
dialogues.text: You sure you don’t want to stay the night? Got some fine brandy and a couple of choice wenches in the cellar. We can get Abner to strike up the fiddle, sit around the fire and tell old lies. Just then, Randall's daughter LILLY (9) emerges from insi She dons a white dress with a matching ribbon in her hair she gleefully descends the stairs, we notice a tweed rope her grip. We follow its length to the opposite end to fin It's tied around the neck of a NINE YEAR OLD SLAVE GIRL. The slave child giggles as she follows Lilly to the front yard where they frolic through a game of follow the leade ANGLE ON NAT who watches on, abashed.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: We best be gettin’ back before nightfall. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ae  6/15/15 - YELLOW 45a

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH RANDALL
dialogues.text: Alright, suit yourself. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: But I would take a bottle of whiskey if you can spare it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH RANDALL
dialogues.text: Sure can. Abner disappears inside. Randall produces a wad of bills, hands it to Samuel. He studies it a beat, before pocketin

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH RANDALL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're a smart man, Sam. Bound to make a fortune off that boy. (extends his hand) Good doing business with ya.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: (shakes ) sure. As Samuel climbs onto the front of the wagon, Abner retur hands him a bottle of whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: ABNER
dialogues.text: His eyes locked tight on Nat. Nat holds his gaze until he spots Jasper further down the road waving goodbye. Nat sn the reins and the wagon lurches forward. Samuel wastes no time popping the cork on the whiskey, pulling a desperate swig. INT. SLAVE QUARTERS - NAT’S CABIN - (NIGHT) 60 A wooden muddler mixes grease in a wooden bowl. A hands scoops at the substance and we follow it to reveal Cherry applying it to Nat’s back. She rubs at his muscles as he stares absently into the flame of the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: You alright? Nat nods, his eyes settle on Cherry’s dress draped across wooden table across the room.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: That dress there. That the one you were wearing that day?

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Mama didn't offer you one of hers? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: She did. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nat looks to Cherry puzzled. A beat before Cherry rises, grabs the dress before returning to bed. She flips the bo hem to reveal a square patch sewn into the fabric. A clos look to reveal TWO NAMES AND A DATE.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: (reading) Abigail Hayne

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: My momma.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Madison Hayne. Who’s that?

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: That's me. (beat) My momma put this dress on me the day they took me from her. Showed me this here patch. Told me to never forget who I was. That I had a momma. And that she was somewhere missin’ me and lovin’ me. I was thirteen.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I can call you Madison if you like?

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: You can call me whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I'll call you Queen. Cherry smiles a beat before her look turns solemn.

dialogues.speaker: NAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: +++We gonna have a baby.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: A baby? You sure? Cherry nods. Nat slowly swings his feet off the bedside, closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: You mad?

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Mad? Naw. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He pulls her into a tight hug

dialogues.speaker: NAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I ain't mad. He holds her close. We PUSH IN ON NAT, Feeling the weight his fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Nat and Samuel navigate the wagon on a country road. INT. SLAVE BARN/CHURCH - NAT’S CABIN - DAY 62 A very pregnant Cherry lies with Nat as she sounds out wo from the bible. Nat smiles, nods approval.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 64
dialogues.text: EXT. SLAVE QUARTERS - NANA’S CABIN - DAY 65 Cherry sleeps alone in a bed. Widen to reveal Nat in Nana rocking chair. He holds an infant baby girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nat pulls the wagon in front. Samuel looks around.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: Wait here. He drops from the wagon, approaches the front door. Nat climbs down, strokes Jupiter’s mane when the horse suddenly backtracks, spooked. Nat instinctively turns to A GERMAN SHEPHERD races toward him, full tilt! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nat falls to the ground, scurries backwards. Just as the lunges, canines peeled- He's yanked back. The dog fights against the weight of a choke chain, inches from Nat who retreats, pinned against wagon wheel. Nat glances up to find HANK FOWLER (early 30's, a wad of wedged between rotted teeth). A bullwhip rests on one sid his hip, a pistol stowed against his other.

dialogues.speaker: HANK FOWLER
dialogues.text: (calm) Nigger, what you doing on my land? Samuel arrives as Nat pulls himself to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: He’s with me.

dialogues.speaker: HANK FOWLER
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: Samuel Turner. Reverend Walthall sent us.

dialogues.speaker: HANK FOWLER
dialogues.text: You the fella with the nigger preacher. Hank regards Nat with a smug grin.

dialogues.speaker: HANK FOWLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You lucky, boy. I like to’ve let Buster rip yo’ ass to bits. (then, to Samuel) C'mon. Let’s go find Earl. Hank, dog close, heads toward the tobacco fields. Samuel Nat follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank leads Samuel and Nat across the plantation grounds toward the tobacco field.

dialogues.speaker: HANK FOWLER
dialogues.text: Niggers is niggers, here. We don’t treat none no different than another. Preacher or no preacher. We got rules. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK FOWLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The cost of breakin’ ‘em: stealin’ sassin’- or any other thing Earl or me thinks is worth dealin’ with’1l be paid for in skin. You interfere with that, we’ll shoot you where you stand. Hank stops, locks eyes with Samuel

dialogues.speaker: HANK FOWLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Any problems with that, you can stop right now and go on back to where you came from. Nat looks to Samuel who doesn’t budge.

dialogues.speaker: HANK FOWLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank, Samuel and Nat arrive to find EARL FOWLER (Early 40 on horseback, hurling his whip down at toiling slaves. Th whip snaps like gunfire inches from the ears of men, woma and children as they pull leaves from the tobacco plants.

dialogues.speaker: EARL FOWLER
dialogues.text: Come on!

dialogues.speaker: EARL FOWLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: c'mon, nah! CRACK! The whip cracks near the ear of a SLAVE TEEN MALE. teen picks faster. Earl dismounts, holsters his whip.

dialogues.speaker: HANK FOWLER
dialogues.text: Earl, this here’s Sam Turner. Fella with the nigger preacher. Earl hardly glances in their direction. A long beat until dismounts, locks in on Samuel

dialogues.speaker: EARL FOWLER
dialogues.text: Where you say y’all come from? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: Here in Southampton. South of Nottaway.

dialogues.speaker: EARL FOWLER
dialogues.text: Nottaway huh? ...Lotta Yankees makin’ their way down those parts. Come down here, rabble-rousin’, stirring shit on our way of life. A quiet standoff as Earl locks eyes with Samuel, until- a OVERSEER arrives on horseback, pulls Hank aside. Then-

dialogues.speaker: HANK FOWLER
dialogues.text: Earl, got a little problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earl and Hank push in. Nat and Samuel freeze in the doorw their eyes fix on something we don’t yet see.

dialogues.speaker: EARL FOWLER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: HANK FOWLER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That one there.

dialogues.speaker: EARL FOWLER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: HANK FOWLER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Said it’s been ‘bout a day or so.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: TWO MALE SLAVES chained to the wall. One wears an IRON COLLAR, bells on the tips of its reaching horns. A scar b from his temple to his cheek. The other wears an IRON MAS saliva seeping from its sides. Earl squares up with the latter, unlatches his mask. The broken slave can hardly stand.

dialogues.speaker: EARL FOWLER
dialogues.text: You ain't gon’ eat? No response. Earl grabs the nearby bowl of cornmush, puts spoon to the slave’s mouth. He turns away. EARL FOWLER (CONT’D) Aight. (then, more to himself) If it ain’t one thing, it’s the other. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Earl pushes past Nat and out of the room. ON NAT as he studies the tortured men. Earl returns carrying a thick CHISEL, HAMMER AND FUNNEL.

dialogues.speaker: EARL FOWLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Samuel) You wonderin’ why we could use that nigger of yours, you're seeing it first hand. EARL FOWLER (CONT’D) (to Hank) Open his mouth. Grab that cornmeal. Nat and Samuel watch on horrified, as Earl hammers out th male slave’s teeth.

dialogues.speaker: EARL FOWLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If it ain’t the Yanks, it’s the drought... Hank holds the slave’s mouth open, as Earl forces the cornmeal through the funnel and into the man’s throat. Bl teeth and cornmeal seep as he gags. EARL FOWLER (CONT’D) If it ain’t the drought, it’s goddamn mutiny. Earl wipes his hands, regards Nat without missing a beat.

dialogues.speaker: EARL FOWLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Truth is, even the meanest nigger fears the gospel. A good word from your boy here... a disciplined word might go a lot further than my pistol would.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL TURNER
dialogues.text: Well, Nat... he’s a good preacher.

dialogues.speaker: EARL FOWLER
dialogues.text: Don't right mind how good he is. (pointed) Long as he say what he s’pose to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nat stands on the wooden porch flanked by Earl who cradle shotgun. Samuel is a bit further back. A dozen slaves stare wide-eyed. In the BG Hank leads a shackled slave to join the others. This is WILL (30’s, th scar-faced slave we recognizes from previous scene). (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Will stands marred and exhausted, his trembling legs struggling to support his body. NAT regards the assembly, then turns to Earl, eyes averte

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: (low) Mr. Fowler, suh. Regarding my sermon, my plan is to foment in them concupiscence for song.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Concup what? Samuel, out of earshot, looks on with growing concern.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Massa I’m askin’ if you’s opposed to me using singin’ to keep yo’ niggers down? As means to sing away any ‘malignance.’

dialogues.speaker: EARL FOWLER
dialogues.text: That’s fine. Ain’t got no quarrel with singin’. Long as it don’t interfere with they workin’.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Yes, suh. Thank you, suh. Nat turns to the slaves, his subservience thaws, his jaw tightening slightly. NAT (CONT’D) Brethren... I pray you sing to the Lord a new song. Sing praise in the assembly of the righteous. Let the saints be joyful in glory; Let them sing aloud on their beds. Let the high praises of God be in the mouths of the saints, and a two- edged sword in their hand, to execute vengeance on the demonic nations, and punishments on those peoples! Nat builds, as Samuel studies Earl, who watches on seemin oblivious to Nat’s innuendos.

dialogues.speaker: NAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To bind their kings with chains, And their nobles with fetters of iron; To execute on them this written judgment— (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Crowd members observe, rapt. Will glances toward Nat.

dialogues.speaker: NAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This honor have all His saints! Praise the Lord! Sing to Him a new song!

dialogues.speaker: CROWD MEMBERS
dialogues.text: -Hallelujah! -Amen! -Yes Lord! On Nat, regaining his bearings. A female VOICE OS starts spiritual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cherry pumps water from a well near the forest’s edge. As fills a bucket, she hears a SOUND. She glances up to see- COBB, eyes glued on hers.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: What you doing out so late, girl?

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: Evenin’, suh. I’m just pulling water for the missus.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: I don’t suppose you got a pass anywhere under that purty dress?

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: No suh. I belongs to Massa Guiles and this here his property.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: You sassin’ me, girl?

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: No suh.

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: Anybody that knows nothing, knows state law says “if a nigger is less than ten paces from the treeline, that nigger needs a pass.” Cherry eyes the treeline, which lies only a few feet away

dialogues.speaker: CHERRY
dialogues.text: Well suh, I can go get one- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COBB
dialogues.text: You aint goin’ no where. Either you're gonna show me a pass... Or you gon’ show me something else. Cobb takes a step forward. Cherry steps back, right into-

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Another of Cobb’s men emerges from the trees surrounding Off Cobb’s contorted smile, we-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isaiah pulls a robe tight as he reaches the front door. H opens it to find Nat, distraught. Isaiah steps onto the porch, closing the door behind him. They speak in whisper

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: I need to talk to Samuel.

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH
dialogues.text: Samuel has retired for the evenin’.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Cherry's been hurt. I need a pass to go see her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH
dialogues.text: I just said, he’s retired.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: And I just said Cherry, my wife, your sister in Christ has been hurt-

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH
dialogues.text: It's going to have to wait til mornin’.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: Isaiah, if you don’t go get Samuel, right now, I’m gonna go get him myself.

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH
dialogues.text: And what if he doesn’t let you go? (xe: Nat’s no answer) Let me guess, you gonna go anyway? (no answer) Nat, I’m real sorry for whatever happened to Cherry, but you can’t run around here with your chest poked out making demands. We are niggers! I'd have thought you'd learned by now.

dialogues.speaker: NAT
dialogues.text: We ain't niggers, Isaiah. We men. I'd have thought you’d learn that by now. And with that, Nat reaches past Isaiah, opens the door an strides into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nat bounds the stairs, Isaiah races to get in front. Jani emerges from her quarters, Isaiah waves her back in. At t top of the stairs, Isaiah cuts off Nat’s path.

dialogues.speaker: ISAIAH

dialogues.text: Our hands often go from field to house when needed. Not every family treats their slaves with your level of savagery.

dialogues.text: And he gave you a pass? (CONTINUED)
